panels.description:
Avg is shown here, just so we know that we are configuring our buckets right.

More info about how avg can help us with bucket configuration can be seen at Tom Wilkie's RED Method talk.

links.title: How avg help us configure representative Prometheus histogram buckets

panels.title: Regular workspace startup time

links.title: How avg help us configure representative Prometheus histogram buckets
How avg help us configure representative Prometheus histogram buckets

targets.expr: sum(workqueue_depth{job="ws-manager-mk2", pod=~"$pod", name=~"$controller"}) by (cluster, pod, name)
sum(rate(controller_runtime_reconcile_total{job="ws-manager-mk2", pod=~"$pod", controller=~"$controller"}[5m])) by (cluster, pod, controller, result)
topk(20, max(workqueue_longest_running_processor_seconds{job="ws-manager-mk2", pod=~"$pod", name=~"$controller"}) by (cluster, pod, name))

sum(
    rate(grpc_server_handling_seconds_sum{job="ws-manager-mk2", cluster=~"$cluster", grpc_method="$grpc_method"}[5m])
  ) by (cluster, grpc_method)
  /
  sum(
    rate(grpc_server_handling_seconds_count{job="ws-manager-mk2", cluster=~"$cluster", grpc_method="$grpc_method"}[5m])
  ) by (cluster, grpc_method)

panels.description:
Saturation > 100% means that the container is requesting more than its limits.

Kubernetes will start to throttle CPU when that happens. That's a sign of degraded performance.

'No Data' indicates that the pod has no CPU limits.
panels.title: CPU Saturation

targets.expr: sum(container_memory_working_set_bytes{container!="POD", container!="", cluster=~"$cluster", node=~"$node", pod=~"$pod"}) by (pod, cluster, node)

panels.description:
Memory can't be throttled. When a container reaches 100% of its memory limits,  Kubernetes will kill the container and restart it.

'No Data' indicates that the pod doesn't have Memory limits.
panels.title: Memory Saturation
Memory Usage (as seen by the runtime process)
CPU Usage (as seen by the runtime process)
